title: How can one get signed to a record label as a music producer? - Quora

response.answer_text: The problem in modern music industry is that there are more and more music producers coming into picture each day and not all of them are equally talented. Marketing and exposure hence matters more than the actual talent of the artist especially in the genre of EDM. Getting signed to a record label, at least a free one is both challenging and crucial for a sustainable career in music production. However, having a good knowledge base of music theory and sound design along with composition and production skills is more important than anything else. If you think that your music is up to the mark, considering the quality requirements of a record label you should start getting feedback on your work too. There are many contests like like Spinnin’ Records’ Talent Pool contest and demo submissions for Revealed Recordings, Monstercat, NoCopyrightSounds etc. but they need some marketing strategies and sometimes capital investment for you to ever get signed. AMATEUR RECORDS is an independent free Record Label that offers publishing of royalty free, no copyright music for exposure and marketing. You can submit your music for verification and assignment to AMATEUR RECORDS for free and it will be distributed over platforms like YouTube and SoundCloud. Get connected to this startup record label and give a kickstart to your career by getting signed. Let’s make music industry a better place together by building a community of talented and deserving artists. Submit your best work to us…

Treat music like business. Where are people finding your genre of music? Many times, I produce Future Bass. So i will be intrested in question, “Where people are going for future bass songs?”. Is it from youtube, is it soundcloud or is it spotify. Identify where the audience cones from and target it with your music.Make avprofessional, unique sounding music. Make sure your mixes are as loud as professional tracks and you don’t sound like any amateur artist.Promote your music in a different way. If your friend makes youtube videos, tell him to use one of your songs in his vidoes and make sure he puts your name & channel link in credit section. So if viewers like music, they can check out your channel. You can actually pay a youtuber to use your music in their videos.If you are not a big artist, release a remix of a fresh song before you release your original. This can get you a significant amount of traffic on your channel as people will be searching remixes of that song and if they like your remix, that subscribe button should be irresistable for them.You can name your song after a well known song. If viewers are searching that song on youtube, your song will also pop out along with that song. That increases your chances to be recognised.Hope this helps. I got this tips from Zen World on his blog Evosounds. Check him out on youtube, he is amazing. Aaditya. Peace out!!!

By being good at what they do… no matter what professional skills you have if you are good enough you will get more work and in turn more exposure to the right contacts.. My venture into professional and commercial production as a mixture of the popularity of the music I was making and being in the right place right time with the right person… so for close to 30 years I've produced and remixed on a number of independent labels around the world and even ran my own for a short time… even now I don't really approach producers with demos, I established my own place so instead I get artists hiring me as their producer/ghost writer/remixer on top of the tv, radio and game jingles… I work close with original artists on remix projects as a sole producer to create the exact opposite of their own music, flipping the script and changing the genre… even if the original atist label rejects it I've built up enough of my own reputation and can easily obtain a mechanical licence for releasing unofficial bootlegs on smaller labels

Do you mean music producer in the electronic music sense of an artist that fully produces their own music or do you mean a music producer who produces the music of a separate artist? If it’s the former then what you do is you send the label your music and ask them if they’re interested in releasing it. Even if they are it’s unlikely that they’ll sign you up to a long term contract. Usually they’ll prefer to sign just the tracks that they like. It’s only once you’ve built a history of releases and have an eager audience for your new music that any label would want to risk signing any longer term contract. If it’s the latter then it’s unlikely that you’ll get any type of long term contract. Your only contracts will be on a project by project basis.

Labels don’t generally sign producers. They sign artists. They do hire producers to assist in making records rather frequently though. They look for similar things that they look for in artists. Talent and potential. In order for a label to show interest in you as a producer you will need to be making successful recordings already. So get writing and recording with other artists and publish that music. When you’ve had some success and it looks like you are capable of having far more success then they will be ringing you.

I agree with Mark Bowyer’s answer. Labels mainly doesn’t hire producers unless they are one of the tycoon ones like Sony, Universal and Warner Bros or their subsidiaries. Anyhow, you don’t need a record label really to demonstrate your work through. You can simply start to sign with music PR and digital marketing agencies, who will handle your work and plan your ideas and start to promote for you among several music platforms and through social media platforms as well. There are hundreds of companies that you can work with them, some are so specialized in specific music genres and others are not. My advice you can even sign with different ones at once. You just start working independently with artists. Hopefully you find a great artist to come up with. Sometimes it’s just having your beat discovered by a big artist then the label finds out about you. There’s so many different paths, but you have to start by making original, unique beats and list them on Beat Stars and start to market yourself and get noticed. It takes years sometimes, so don’t stop. The main problem I’ve seen with producers and artists is they get lazy or stop when they release some tracks and don’t have success.

My experience is a bit old, but American record labels usually do not sign producers, they sign the recording artists, themselves. The producers I worked with are contracted by the label for the project. Some artists contract their own producers.
You have to get a reputation as a production-engineer or demo producer whose work ends up on the B sides. The labels then add your name to the Producer list they give artists.
